abstract_summ: SARS-CoV-2 infection has the potential for targeting central nervous system and several neurological symptoms have been described in patients with severe respiratory distress.Covid‐19 infection has the potential for targeting the central nervous system and several neurological symptoms have been described in patients with severe respiratory distress.Hence, COVID-19 patients can develop psychotic symptoms as a consequence of multiple concurrent factors.The patient dramatically improved after high-doses steroid treatment suggesting an inflammatory-mediated brain involvement related to SARS-CoV-2 infectionThis is a case report of a 42-year-old patient, who was admitted to hospital with clinical pneumonia.Ten patients infected by the novel coronavirus with psychotic symptoms and no previous history of psychosis were identified by the emergency and liaison psychiatry departments.
title_summ: A RETROSPECTIVE DESCRIPTIVE STUDY.A Unique Presentation of Delirium in a Patient with Otherwise Asymptomatic COVID‐19SARS-CoV-2 can induce brain and spine demyelinating lesionsEvolution and resolution of brain involvement associated with SARS- CoV2 infection: A close Clinical – Paraclinical follow up study of a caseDe Novo Status Epilepticus in patients with COVID‐19A Case of Catatonia in a Man with COVID-19Steroid-responsive severe encephalopathy in SARS-CoV-2 infection[COVID-19 associated severe psychotic relapse].Multiple Sclerosis following SARS-CoV-2 infectionFocal status epilepticus as unique clinical feature of COVID-19: a case reportSteroid‐responsive encephalitis in Covid‐19 diseaseFirst Case of Focal Epilepsy Associated with SARS‐Coronavirus‐2PSYCHOTIC SYMPTOMS IN COVID-19 PATIENTS.
title_abstract_phrases: Steroid-responsive severe encephalopathy in SARS-CoV-2 infectionSARS-CoV-2 infection has the potential for targeting central nervous system and several neurological symptoms have been described in patients with severe respiratory distress.Steroid‐responsive encephalitis in Covid‐19 diseaseCovid‐19 infection has the potential for targeting the central nervous system and several neurological symptoms have been described in patients with severe respiratory distress.Here we described the case of an otherwise healthy 60-year old subject with SARS-CoV-2 infection but only mild respiratory abnormalities who developed severe progressive encephalopathy associated with mild pleocytosis and hyperproteinorrachia.Hence, COVID-19 patients can develop psychotic symptoms as a consequence of multiple concurrent factors.The patient dramatically improved after high-doses steroid treatment suggesting an inflammatory-mediated brain involvement related to SARS-CoV-2 infection[COVID-19 associated severe psychotic relapse].This is a case report of a 42-year-old patient, who was admitted to hospital with clinical pneumonia.
